assignments.rationale: The peak at ~1580 cm⁻¹ is characteristic of the G band in graphite, corresponding to the E2g phonon at the Brillouin zone center, indicative of sp2 hybridized carbon atoms.
assignments.literature_reference: Ferrari, A. C., & Robertson, J. (2000). Physical Review B, 61(20), 14095-14107. DOI:10.1103/PhysRevB.61.14095

assignments.rationale: Carbon nanotubes exhibit a G band around this frequency due to tangential C-C stretching vibrations, similar to graphite, but with slight shifts depending on tube diameter and chirality.
PAHs can show Raman peaks around 1580 cm⁻¹ due to C-C stretching modes in the aromatic rings, although the peak is typically less intense compared to graphite.
assignments.literature_reference: Sadezky, A., Muckenhuber, H., Grothe, H., Niessner, R., & Pöschl, U. (2005). Carbon, 43(8), 1731-1742. DOI:10.1016/j.carbon.2005.02.018

summary.analysis_overview: The Raman peak at 1579.94 cm⁻¹ is most likely the G band of graphite, a common feature in sp2 carbon materials. The intensity and narrow FWHM support this assignment.
summary.key_literature_findings: Ferrari and Robertson (2000) provide a comprehensive analysis of the G band in graphite. Carbon nanotubes also show similar features, but with variations due to structural differences.
summary.alternative_considerations: While carbon nanotubes and PAHs can show similar peaks, the specific characteristics of the peak, such as intensity and FWHM, align more closely with graphite.

references: Ferrari, A. C., & Robertson, J. (2000). Physical Review B, 61(20), 14095-14107. DOI:10.1103/PhysRevB.61.14095
Sadezky, A., Muckenhuber, H., Grothe, H., Niessner, R., & Pöschl, U. (2005). Carbon, 43(8), 1731-1742. DOI:10.1016/j.carbon.2005.02.018

assignments.vibrational_mode: 2D band (second order of the D band)
assignments.rationale: The 2D band in graphite is a second-order overtone of the D band, commonly observed around 2700 cm⁻¹. It is a prominent feature in the Raman spectrum of graphite and graphene materials.
assignments.literature_reference: Ferrari, A.C., & Robertson, J. (2000). Physical Review B. DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.61.14095

assignments.vibrational_mode: G' band (second order of the D band)
assignments.rationale: Similar to graphite, carbon nanotubes exhibit a G' band around 2670 cm⁻¹, which is a second-order process related to the D band. This peak is indicative of the presence of sp2 hybridized carbon structures.
assignments.literature_reference: Dresselhaus, M.S., et al. (2005). Physics Reports. DOI: 10.1016/j.physrep.2005.03.003

assignments.rationale: PAHs can exhibit overtones of C-H stretching modes in the high wavenumber region. However, the intensity and position are less consistent compared to graphite-related materials.
assignments.literature_reference: Hudgins, D.M., & Allamandola, L.J. (1999). The Astrophysical Journal. DOI: 10.1086/306965

summary.analysis_overview: The peak at 2670.19 cm⁻¹ is characteristic of the 2D band in graphite, a common feature in carbon-based materials with sp2 hybridization.
summary.key_literature_findings: The literature consistently identifies the 2D band in graphite and graphene materials around this wavenumber, with strong intensity and a relatively narrow FWHM.
summary.alternative_considerations: While carbon nanotubes and PAHs can exhibit similar features, the prominence and specificity of the 2D band in graphite make it the most likely assignment.

references: Ferrari, A.C., & Robertson, J. (2000). Physical Review B. DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.61.14095
Dresselhaus, M.S., et al. (2005). Physics Reports. DOI: 10.1016/j.physrep.2005.03.003
Hudgins, D.M., & Allamandola, L.J. (1999). The Astrophysical Journal. DOI: 10.1086/306965
